docs.title: Sync-Repos Tool Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the official documentation for the sync-repos tool, a private DevOps utility designed to synchronize files between directories or Git repositories. This tool is distributed as a .deb package and hosted in a private Bitbucket repository (supratimneogi007/syncmaster).

docs.title: About
docs.text:
• Version: 2.7.3
  • Last Updated: March 20, 2025
  • Maintainer: Supratim Neogi (supratimneogi007)

This documentation provides instructions for DevOps employees to install and use the tool, as well as guidance for developers to maintain it. Navigate the sections below for detailed information.

docs.title: Sections
docs.text:
• Installation
  • Usage
  • Guide
  • Maintenance
  • Troubleshooting

docs.title: 📋 Overview
docs.text: The syncRepoV3_LTS.sh script is a powerful tool designed to synchronize files between source and destination directories or Git repositories. It provides robust features for backup, rollback, and Git operations. After installation, you can run it from any directory using the sync_repo command.

docs.title: 📂 File Synchronization
docs.text:
• Seamlessly sync files between directories or Git repositories
  • Support for both local paths and remote Git repositories
  • Intelligent handling of Git branches

docs.title: 🔄 Backup and Rollback
docs.text:
• Automatic Backups: Creates backups before any synchronization
  • Multiple Rollback Options:
  • --rb: Rollback to latest backup
  • --rlp: Rollback the last Git push
  • --rtc: Rollback to a specific Git commit

docs.title: 🔧 Git Integration
docs.text:
• Pull latest changes from source repositories
  • Commit and push changes to destination repositories
  • Branch management and switching

docs.title: 📊 Repository Tracking
docs.text:
• Track repositories with unique operation IDs
  • Edit repository information with user-friendly interface
  • View all tracked repositories in a formatted display

docs.title: 📝 Comprehensive Logging
docs.text:
• Detailed JSON-based logs for all operations
  • Logs organized by date for easy reference
  • View logs directly from the command line

docs.title: 🗂️ Directory Structure
docs.text:
The script creates the following directory structure:

~/.sync_repo/
├── BACKUP/          # Stores timestamped backup archives
├── LOGS/            # Contains detailed operation logs
│   └── DD_Month/    # Organized by date (e.g., 25_March)
├── SYNC_DIR/
│   ├── YYYY_MM_REPOS/  # Repositories organized by month
│   │   └── DD/      # And day
│   │       ├── source_DIR_XXXXXX/  # Source repositories
│   │       └── dest_DIR_XXXXXX/    # Destination repositories
│   └── repo_tracking.json  # Repository tracking information

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Install required dependencies
sudo apt install git rsync jq tar

# Run the script directly
bash curl -L -u "<your-username>:<your-app-password>" -O "https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/supratimneogi007/syncmaster/downloads/sync-repos_2.7.3_all.deb" && sudo apt install ./sync-repos_2.7.3_all.deb

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
# Perform file synchronization
sync_repo --i

# Rollback to latest backup
sync_repo --rb

# Edit repository tracking information
sync_repo --edit-track

docs.title: 📚 Command Reference
docs.text: Command Alias Description Example --i Perform file synchronization sync_repo --i --rb Rollback to latest backup sync_repo --rb --rlp Rollback last Git push sync_repo --rlp --rtc Rollback to specific commit sync_repo --rtc --edit-track -et Edit repository tracking sync_repo --edit-track --show-ids -id Show operation IDs sync_repo --show-ids --clear-backups Clear backup folder sync_repo --clear-backups --show-logs Display available logs sync_repo --show-logs --version Show script version sync_repo --version --help -h Display help information sync_repo --help

docs.title: Example 1: Syncing Between Two Git Repositories
docs.text:
# Start synchronization process
sync_repo --i

# When prompted, enter Git URLs:
# Source: git@github.com:username/source-repo.git
# Destination: git@github.com:username/destination-repo.git
# Follow the prompts to complete the sync

docs.title: Example 2: Using Operation IDs for Quick Access
docs.text:
# First, view available operation IDs
sync_repo --show-ids

# Then use the operation ID for syncing
sync_repo --i
# When prompted, select option 2 for operation ID
# Enter the ID shown from --show-ids command

docs.title: Example 3: Rollback After a Failed Sync
docs.text:
# If a sync operation causes issues, roll back
sync_repo --rb

# Confirm the rollback when prompted

docs.title: Working with Branches
docs.text:
The script allows you to specify and switch branches:

  1. Edit a repository's branch: bash sync_repo --edit-track # Select the repository and choose option 3 to edit branch

  2. When cloning a new repository, you'll be prompted for branch name: Enter branch name for source repository [main]: develop

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This script, sync_repos.sh, is designed to synchronize files between source and destination directories or Git repositories. It includes features for backup, rollback, and Git operation capabilities. The script is packaged as a .deb file and can be executed using the sync_repo command from any directory.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
1. File Synchronization:
  2. Synchronizes files between source and destination directories.

  3. Supports Git repositories as source or destination.

  4. Backup and Rollback:

  5. Automatically creates backups before synchronization.

  6. Rollback options:

    • Rollback to the latest backup.
    • Rollback the last Git push.
    • Rollback to a specific Git commit.

  7. Git Operations:

  8. Pulls the latest changes from the source repository.

  9. Allows committing and pushing changes to the destination repository.

  10. Tracking:

  11. Maintains a JSON-based tracking file for repositories.

  12. Allows editing repository information (e.g., URL, branch, path).

  13. Logging:

  14. Logs all operations in JSON format for easy debugging and auditing.

  15. Centralized Directory:

  16. Stores all logs, backups, and tracking files in a centralized directory ($HOME/.sync_repo).

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
The script creates and uses the following directory structure under $HOME/.sync_repo:

~/.sync_repo/
├── BACKUP/          # Stores backup files
├── LOGS/            # Stores log files
│   └── <date>/      # Logs are organized by date
├── SYNC_DIR/
│   ├── SOURCE_DIR/  # Source repositories
│   └── DEST_DIR/    # Destination repositories
└── repo_tracking.json  # JSON file to track repository information

docs.title: Command Syntax
docs.text: sync_repo [OPTION]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --rb Rollback to the latest backup. --rlp Rollback the last Git push. --rtc Rollback to a specific Git commit. --i Perform file synchronization. --edit-track Edit the repository tracking file. --show-ids Show operation IDs for repositories. --clear-backups Clear the backup folder. -et Alias for --edit-track. -id Alias for --show-ids. -h, --help Display usage information.

docs.title: Setup and Initialization
docs.text:
1. Centralized Directory:

  2. The script automatically creates the centralized directory ($HOME/.sync_repo) and its subdirectories if they do not exist.

  3. Required Commands:

  4. Ensure the following commands are installed on your system:

    • tar
    • rsync
    • git
    • jq

  5. Environment Variables:

  6. The script supports a .env file for development purposes. If present, it loads environment variables from .env.

docs.title: 1. Initialization
docs.text:
• initialize():
  • Ensures the centralized directory and required subdirectories exist.
  • Prompts the user for source and destination paths.
  • Initializes the log file and tracking file.

docs.title: 2. Logging
docs.text:
• initialize_log_file():
  • Creates a new log file in the LOGS directory.

  • Redirects script output to the log file.

  • log_message(type, message):

  • Logs messages in JSON format to the log file.

docs.title: 3. Backup and Rollback
docs.text:
• sync_files():
  • Creates a backup of the destination directory.

  • Synchronizes files from the source to the destination.

  • rollback():

  • Restores the destination directory from the latest backup.

  • rollback_last_push():

  • Rolls back the last Git push in the destination repository.

  • rollback_to_commit(commit_hash):

  • Rolls back the destination repository to a specific commit.

docs.title: 4. Git Operations
docs.text:
• clone_if_needed(input, type, var_name):

  • Clones a Git repository if it is not already tracked.

  • update_repository_branch(repo_path, new_branch, repo_url):

  • Switches or updates the branch of a Git repository.

  • git_operations():

  • Handles Git add, commit, and push operations for the destination repository.

docs.title: 5. Tracking
docs.text:
• edit_tracking_file():

  • Allows the user to edit repository information in the tracking file.

  • show_operation_ids():

  • Displays a list of tracked repositories with their operation IDs.

docs.title: 6. Cleanup
docs.text:
• clear_backups():
  • Deletes all backups in the BACKUP directory.

docs.title: Development Guidelines
docs.text:
1. Adding New Features:
  2. Follow the existing structure for logging and error handling.

  3. Ensure new features integrate with the centralized directory structure.

  4. Testing:

  5. Test the script in both development and production environments.

  6. Use mock repositories for testing Git operations.

  7. Error Handling:

  8. Use log_message to log errors and warnings.

  9. Exit the script gracefully on critical errors.

  10. Documentation:

  11. Update this README.md file whenever new features are added.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
1. Permission Issues:

  2. Ensure the script has write access to $HOME/.sync_repo.

  3. Missing Commands:

  4. Install missing commands using your package manager (e.g., sudo apt install jq).

  5. Git Errors:

  6. Verify that the source and destination repositories are accessible and have the correct permissions.

  7. Tracking File Corruption:

  8. If the repo_tracking.json file is corrupted, delete it and let the script recreate it.

docs.title: Future Enhancements
docs.text:
1. Multi-User Support:

  2. Add support for system-wide usage with /var/lib/sync_repo.

  3. Improved Logging:

  4. Add log rotation and archiving for older logs.

  5. Web Interface:

  6. Develop a web-based interface for managing repositories and tracking files.

  7. Advanced Rollback:

  8. Add options for partial rollbacks (e.g., specific files or directories).

docs.title: Sync Repositories Tool - User Guide
docs.text: This document provides a detailed guide on how to use the sync-repos tool for synchronizing files, managing backups, and handling Git repositories. The tool is designed to be user-friendly and supports various operations like rollback, editing tracking files, and displaying logs.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Run the tool with one of the following options:

sync-repos [OPTION]

docs.title: 1. --i - Perform File Synchronization
docs.text:
Synchronizes files between the source and destination directories or Git repositories. This operation includes: - Pulling the latest changes from the source repository. - Backing up the destination directory before syncing. - Synchronizing files while excluding .git and node_modules.

Detailed Steps: 1. Run the following command: bash sync-repos --i

  1. Source Directory Selection:
  2. You will see a prompt: "Source Directory - Choose an option: (1) GIT URL (2) OP_ID"
  3. Enter 1 to provide a Git URL or 2 to provide an Operation ID (OP_ID).

If you chose option 1 (GIT URL): - You will see: "Enter Git URL:" - Enter the complete Git URL (e.g., https://github.com/username/repo.git) - You will be prompted: "Enter branch name (default: main):" - Enter the branch name or press Enter to use the default

If you chose option 2 (OP_ID): - You will see: "Enter OP_ID:" - Enter the numerical Operation ID shown from the --show-ids command

  1. Destination Directory Selection:
  2. You will see a prompt: "Destination Directory - Choose an option: (1) GIT URL (2) OP_ID"
  3. Enter 1 to provide a Git URL or 2 to provide an Operation ID (OP_ID).

If you chose option 1 (GIT URL): - You will see: "Enter Git URL:" - Enter the complete Git URL for the destination repository - You will be prompted: "Enter branch name (default: main):" - Enter the branch name or press Enter to use the default

If you chose option 2 (OP_ID): - You will see: "Enter OP_ID:" - Enter the numerical Operation ID for the destination repository

  1. Backup Creation:
  2. The system will display: "Creating backup of destination directory..."
  3. A progress indicator will show the backup creation process

  4. You'll see a confirmation message once the backup is complete with the backup filename

  5. Pull Latest Changes:

  6. The system will display: "Pulling latest changes from source repository..."

  7. Git pull output will be shown as changes are retrieved

  8. File Synchronization:

  9. The system will display: "Synchronizing files..."
  10. You'll see rsync output showing which files are being copied/updated

  11. A confirmation message will appear once synchronization is complete

  12. Git Operations:

  13. You will be prompted: "Do you want to perform Git operations? (yes/no)"

If you choose "yes": - The system will display the Git status showing new/modified/deleted files - You will be prompted: "Do you want to add all changes? (yes/no)"

If you choose "yes" to add changes: - The system will execute git add . and show the output - You will be prompted: "Enter commit message:" - Enter your descriptive commit message - The system will create the commit and show the commit hash - You will be prompted: "Do you want to push changes? (yes/no)"

If you choose "yes" to push changes: - The system will push the changes to the remote repository - You'll see the Git push output and confirmation

If you choose "no" at any point: - The operation will skip to the next step or finish if it's the last step

  1. Operation Complete:
  2. The system will display: "Synchronization completed successfully."
  3. You'll be returned to the command prompt

Example:

sync-repos --i

docs.title: 2. --show-ids, -id - Show Operation IDs
docs.text:
Displays a list of all tracked repositories along with their operation IDs, repository URLs, branches, and paths.

Detailed Steps: 1. Run the following command: bash sync-repos --show-ids

  1. View Repository Information:
  2. The system will display a formatted table showing:
    • OP_ID (numeric identifier)
    • Repository URL
    • Branch name
    • Local repository path

  3. No further input is required for this command

  4. Using the Information:

  5. Note down any OP_IDs you need for other operations
  6. Press any key to return to the command prompt if prompted

Example:

sync-repos --show-ids

+-------+----------------------------------------+---------+--------------------------------+
| OP_ID |               REPO URL                 | BRANCH  |              PATH              |
+-------+----------------------------------------+---------+--------------------------------+
|   1   | https://github.com/user/repo1.git      | main    | /home/user/repositories/repo1  |
|   2   | https://github.com/user/repo2.git      | develop | /home/user/repositories/repo2  |
|   3   | https://github.com/org/project.git     | feature | /home/user/work/project        |
+-------+----------------------------------------+---------+--------------------------------+

docs.title: 3. --rb - Rollback to the Latest Backup
docs.text:
Restores the destination directory to its most recent backup.

Detailed Steps: 1. Run the following command: bash sync-repos --rb

  1. Backup Selection:
  2. The system will display: "Searching for latest backup..."
  3. It will automatically locate the most recent backup file

  4. You'll see: "Latest backup found: [backup filename]"

  5. Confirmation:

  6. You will be prompted: "Do you want to restore from this backup? (yes/no)"

  7. Enter yes to proceed or no to cancel the operation

  8. Restoration Process:

  9. If you chose "yes":
    • The system will display: "Restoring from backup..."
    • You'll see the extraction progress as files are restored
    • Upon completion, you'll see: "Restoration completed successfully."

  10. If you chose "no":

    • The operation will be cancelled with a message: "Restoration cancelled."

  11. Cleanup:

  12. The system will ask: "Do you want to delete the used backup file? (yes/no)"
  13. Enter yes to delete the backup file or no to keep it
  14. If you chose "yes", you'll see: "Backup file deleted."

Example:

sync-repos --rb

Do you want to restore from this backup? (yes/no)

docs.title: 4. --edit-track, -et - Edit the Repository Tracking File
docs.text:
Allows you to edit the tracking file that stores information about repositories.

Detailed Steps: 1. Run the following command: bash sync-repos --edit-track

  1. Repository List Display:
  2. The system will display a table of all tracked repositories

  3. You'll see OP_IDs, URLs, branches, and paths for all repositories

  4. Repository Selection:

  5. You will be prompted: "Enter the OP_ID of the repository you want to edit:"

  6. Enter the numeric OP_ID of your target repository

  7. Field Selection:

  8. You will see: "Choose the field to update:"
  9. ```
    1. Repository URL
    2. Path
    3. Branch
    4. Operation ID ```

  10. Enter the number corresponding to the field you want to edit

  11. Value Update:

  12. Based on your field selection:
    • For Repository URL: "Enter new Repository URL:"
    • For Path: "Enter new Path:"
    • For Branch: "Enter new Branch:"
    • For Operation ID: "Enter new Operation ID:"

  13. Enter the new value for the selected field

  14. Confirmation:

docs.title: 6. --clear-backups - Clear the Backup Folder
docs.text:
Deletes all backups stored in the backup folder.

Detailed Steps: 1. Run the following command: bash sync-repos --clear-backups

  1. Backup Summary:
  2. The system will display: "Found [number] backup files in the backup folder."

  3. You'll see the total size of the backup files: "Total size: [size] MB"

  4. Confirmation:

  5. You will be prompted: "Are you sure you want to delete all backups? (yes/no)"

  6. Enter yes to proceed with deletion or no to cancel

  7. Deletion Process:

  8. If you chose "yes":
    • The system will display: "Deleting backups..."
    • A progress indicator or list of files being deleted may be shown
    • Upon completion, you'll see: "All backups have been deleted successfully."
  9. If you chose "no":
    • The operation will be cancelled with a message: "Operation cancelled. Backups were not deleted."

Example:

sync-repos --clear-backups

docs.title: 7. --rlp - Rollback the Last Git Push
docs.text:
Reverts the last Git push in the destination repository.

Detailed Steps: 1. Run the following command: bash sync-repos --rlp

  1. Repository Selection:
  2. You will be prompted: "Enter the OP_ID of the repository to rollback:"

  3. Enter the numeric OP_ID of the repository

  4. Current Status Check:

  5. The system will display: "Checking current repository status..."

  6. You'll see the current HEAD commit hash and message

  7. Previous Commit Identification:

  8. The system will display: "Previous commit: [commit hash]"

  9. You'll see the commit message and details

  10. Confirmation:

  11. You will be prompted: "Are you sure you want to rollback to this commit? (yes/no)"

  12. Enter yes to proceed with the rollback or no to cancel

  13. Rollback Process:

  14. If you chose "yes":

    • The system will display: "Rolling back to previous commit..."
    • You'll see Git output as the repository is reset
    • You will be prompted: "Do you want to force push this rollback? (yes/no)"

    If you choose "yes" to force push: - The system will display: "Force pushing rollback..." - You'll see Git output as changes are pushed - Upon completion, you'll see: "Rollback has been successfully pushed."

    If you choose "no" to force push: - The operation will finish locally with a message: "Rollback completed locally but not pushed."

  15. If you chose "no" at the initial confirmation:

    • The operation will be cancelled with a message: "Rollback cancelled."

Example:

sync-repos --rlp

Enter the OP_ID of the repository to rollback:
2

Checking current repository status...
Current HEAD: 8a2b3c4 - Update utils and documentation

Previous commit: a1b2c3d - Fix pagination in API responses

Are you sure you want to rollback to this commit? (yes/no)
yes

Rolling back to previous commit...
HEAD is now at a1b2c3d Fix pagination in API responses

Do you want to force push this rollback? (yes/no)
yes

Force pushing rollback...
Total 0 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
To https://github.com/user/repo2.git
 + 8a2b3c4...a1b2c3d develop -> develop (forced update)

Rollback has been successfully pushed.

docs.title: 8. --rtc - Rollback to a Specific Git Commit
docs.text:
Rolls back the destination repository to a specific Git commit.

Detailed Steps: 1. Run the following command: bash sync-repos --rtc

  1. Repository Selection:
  2. You will be prompted: "Enter the OP_ID of the repository to rollback:"

  3. Enter the numeric OP_ID of the repository

  4. Commit History Display:

  5. The system will display: "Recent commits in this repository:"

  6. You'll see a list of recent commits with hashes, dates, authors, and messages: 8a2b3c4 (2023-11-28) - John Doe: Update utils and documentation a1b2c3d (2023-11-27) - Jane Smith: Fix pagination in API responses e5f6g7h (2023-11-25) - John Doe: Implement search functionality

  7. Commit Selection:

  8. You will be prompted: "Enter the commit hash you want to rollback to:"

  9. Enter the full or abbreviated commit hash (e.g., "a1b2c3d")

  10. Target Commit Verification:

  11. The system will display: "Selected commit:"

  12. You'll see details of the selected commit including hash, author, date, and message

  13. Confirmation:

  14. You will be prompted: "Are you sure you want to rollback to this commit? (yes/no)"

  15. Enter yes to proceed with the rollback or no to cancel

  16. Rollback Process:

  17. If you chose "yes":

    • The system will display: "Rolling back to selected commit..."
    • You'll see Git output as the repository is reset
    • You will be prompted: "Do you want to force push this rollback? (yes/no)"

    If you choose "yes" to force push: - The system will display: "Force pushing rollback..." - You'll see Git output as changes are pushed - Upon completion, you'll see: "Rollback has been successfully pushed."

    If you choose "no" to force push: - The operation will finish locally with a message: "Rollback completed locally but not pushed."

  18. If you chose "no" at the initial confirmation:

    • The operation will be cancelled with a message: "Rollback cancelled."

Example:

sync-repos --rtc

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• Backup Creation: Before performing any synchronization, the tool automatically creates a backup of the destination directory.
  • Git Operations: After synchronization, you can optionally perform Git operations like adding changes, committing, and pushing to the remote repository.
  • Tracking File: The tool maintains a JSON-based tracking file to store repository information. This file is essential for operations like editing tracking details or showing operation IDs.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Ensure you have the required dependencies installed: git, rsync, tar, and jq.
  2. Clone the tool or copy it to your desired location.
  3. Run the tool with the appropriate option as described above.

For any issues or questions, refer to the logs using the --show-logs option or contact your system administrator.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: This guide provides detailed instructions on how to use the sync-repos tool effectively after installation.

docs.title: Running the Tool
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal and execute the following command: bash sync-repos
  2. Alternatively, use the interactive mode: bash sync-repos --i
  3. Follow the prompts to specify the source and destination paths: bash Enter source path (default: /home/user/.sync-repos/source): /path/to/source Enter destination path (default: /home/user/.sync-repos/dest): /path/to/dest

docs.title: Core Functionality
docs.text:
The sync-repos tool supports synchronization across the following:

  • Local Directories: Copies files and directories while preserving structure, permissions, and timestamps.
  • Git Repositories: Clones or pulls from Git URLs, with rollback and commit-based synchronization options.
  • OP_IDs: Custom identifiers for predefined synchronization tasks (if configured).

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• --rb: Roll back to a previous state.
  • --rlp: Roll back the last push (Git only).
  • --rtc: Roll back to a specific commit (Git only).
  • --edit-track: Edit repos track files.
  • --show-ids: Views repos track files.
  • --help or -h: Display the help menu.

docs.title: Input Handling
docs.text: Accepts source and destination inputs, which can be directories, Git URLs, or OP_IDs.

docs.title: Validation
docs.text: Verifies that the provided paths or URLs are valid and accessible.

docs.title: Synchronization
docs.text:
• For Directories: Uses rsync to efficiently copy files.
  • For Git Repositories: Clones or pulls changes, supporting rollback to prior states.

docs.title: Logging and Backup
docs.text: Generates logs and backups for auditing and recovery.

docs.title: Command-Line Options
docs.text:
Customize the tool’s behavior using the following options:

Option Description --rb Rolls back to a previous synchronization state (directory or Git). --rlp Rolls back the last push (Git repositories only). --rtc Rolls back to a specific commit (Git repositories only). --edit-track Edit repos track files.. --show-ids Views repos track files. --help, -h Displays the help menu with usage details.

docs.title: Rollback to a Previous State
docs.text: sync-repos --rb

docs.title: Rollback Last Git Push
docs.text: sync-repos --rlp

docs.title: Rollback to a Specific Commit
docs.text: sync-repos --rtc <commit-hash>

docs.title: Runtime Artifacts
docs.text: The tool creates and manages files in ~/.sync-repos/ to track synchronization states, logs, and backups. Understanding these artifacts aids in troubleshooting and recovery.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
~/.DevOps_tool/
├── LOGS/
│   └── <date>/            # Logs for each synchronization run
├── BACKUP/                # Backups of synchronized data
├── SYNC_DIR/              # Cloned Git repositories
    └── repo_tracking.json # Tracks synchronization history

docs.title: Logs
docs.text:
• Location: ~/.sync-repos/logs/<date>/
  • Purpose: Records actions, errors, and warnings from each synchronization.

docs.title: Backups
docs.text:
• Location: ~/.sync-repos/backups/
  • Purpose: Stores pre-synchronization backups for rollback.

docs.title: Cloned Repositories
docs.text:
• Location: ~/.sync-repos/SYNC_DIR/
  • Purpose: Holds cloned Git repositories for state management.

docs.title: Tracking File
docs.text:
• File: repo_tracking.json
  • Purpose: Logs synchronization history, including timestamps, paths, and Git commit hashes.

docs.title: Synchronizing Git Repositories
docs.text:
The tool offers enhanced Git support:

  • Cloning: Clones a repository if the destination doesn’t exist.
  • Pulling: Updates an existing destination with the latest changes.
  • Rollback: Reverts to previous commits or states using --rb, --rlp, or --rtc.

docs.title: Example: Sync a Git Repository
docs.text:
sync-repos
Enter source path: https://bitbucket.org/supratimneogi007/syncmaster.git
Enter destination path: /path/to/local/repo

docs.title: Example: Roll Back to a Commit
docs.text: sync-repos --rtc abc123def456

docs.title: Using OP_IDs
docs.text:
For predefined tasks identified by OP_IDs, input the ID instead of paths:

sync-repos --i
Enter source path: OP_ID:12345

The tool maps the OP_ID to configured source and destination paths.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Backup Regularly: While the tool creates backups, manually back up critical data beforehand.
  • Review Logs: Inspect ~/.sync-repos/logs/ after runs to verify success.
  • Stay Updated: Use the latest sync-repos version for improvements and fixes.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Refer to the Troubleshooting section for common issues. For further assistance, contact supratimneogi007@bitbucket.org.

This guide equips your team with a professional, detailed reference to leverage sync-repos effectively, complete with examples and best practices for a seamless experience.
